Message.Title: Obama budget not intended for deficit reduction
Message.Msg: The White House admits that Obama's budget is not set for deficit reduction. The White House began its spin of the president’s budget proposal on Monday as White House Spokesman Jay Carney announced that the president’s proposal would rely heavily on government “investments” instead of private sector growth and that the people should expect large annual budget deficits until 2023 at the earliest. Carney noted that the president is not addressing balancing the budget. “It should not be deficit reduction for deficit reduction’s sake,” he said. “The goal here should be economic growth and job creation.” The economy, however, has been remarkably unstable over the last few years as one economic crisis after another has come up to demand quick action by lawmakers. As America has already raised the debt ceiling several times and crashed through it in the beginning of this year, America is running a $16.6 trillion national debt and the U.S. is continually running deficits of over a trillion dollars with no budget having been passed by the Senate since 2009. If a republican was in the office and did anywhere near as horrible of a job, Yahoo "news" would be comlaining about it every day. Extremely biased Yahoo now just ignores what's going on.

Topic.Title: Barclay's, Needham, B. Riley and Cantor Fitzgerald Give Yahoo $26 PT

Message.Msg: Historically, share buybacks are a poor way for a company to allocate capital. Sure it benfits the shareholder in the short run but in the long run the capital would be better spent on company improvements, expansion, and the like. As an example, imagine you have a $300,000 home with a $100,000 mortage. You get a bonus of $50,000 and decide to "buyback" some of that mortgage by reducing your morgage to only $50,000. Now the good news is you own more of your house, but the value of the house has not changed. Now say instead of "buying back" some of your mortgage, you decide to put on an addition and a nice pool. Now your house is worth more or has more value. The other downside to buybacks is although it reduces the outstanding shares of the company and makes the "per share" financial numbers look better, it also makes the "per share" financials look worse should the company have a bad quarter...which eventually they all have. Overall, buybacks are great short term but a poor allocation of capital for any company. Now I'm sure we can all come up with companies where the share buy back worked out longterm, but overall, in the long run, it's not the best thing for a company to do.

Topic.Title: Barclay's, Needham, B. Riley and Cantor Fitzgerald Give Yahoo $26 PT

Message.Msg: I clearly see your logic. You made a very good point. But I think in YHOO situation it defies your logic to some extent. You see, not only reduced outstanding shares thus increased shareholders values, but unexpected increased of market values of Asian assets I believe increase “additionally” the shareholders values. So double increases come from share buybacks and increase in value of Asian assets. What is your opinion?

Topic.Title: Barclay's, Needham, B. Riley and Cantor Fitzgerald Give Yahoo $26 PT

Message.Msg: goingbravo.....I would agree with you. But they still could put that capital to better use in the long run by expanding their current business or developing new businesses. Clearly the rise in the Asian assets has helped and I wonder how much of that is already priced in. I know all of it is not priced in but a vast majority of it has to be biult into the price at this point.. It's not like no one knows what Yahoo Japan and Alibaba are worth. I'm sure the best minds on Wall Street are calculating that all the time. My real concern is from this point forward. If the global stock markets continue their rise I think Yahoo will perform well. That said, if there is some shock or disruption of some kind and the markets setback back substaintially, it could be a double wammy for Yahoo as it could cause a revaluation of Yahoo Japan, Alibaba, and the likelyhood of an IPO by them. Lofty levels like this make mne pause and re-think the risks. Historially, Yahoo has had some times when the rug has been pulled out from under the share price. Go look at a chart ging back ten years or so. I'm not saying its going to happen here....but its not like its never happened before to Yahoo. As an example, have a look in 2010. From February it went from $14.50 to $19. 15 trading days later it was back below $15.50. Or in 2007 in August it went from $22.50 to $34 by October and 11 trading days later it was back at $25, Again, I not saying this is goin g to happen but rather Yahoo has a history of the share price going balistic and then falling back to earth. And I'm not comfortable thinking "this time is different" which someone is bound to say.

Topic.Title: Barclay's, Needham, B. Riley and Cantor Fitzgerald Give Yahoo $26 PT

Message.Msg: Once again I fully understand your argument and I agree with you considerably. Market disruption such as market correction is always part of the game. Risk is also part of it as well. In other words, investment is somewhat a game of chance. My take also is that Alibaba IPO is mostly priced in to YHOO share but MM and CFO Goldman almost discounted YJ deal, “it is strategic”, and I believe market took it as is, so my thinking is that YJ is not even in the equation yet as far as YHOO share appreciation is concerned. So if the latter is announced that MM/Goldman would like to make a deal with say Softbank/YJ management, I think YHOO share will pop up $5, minimum, my personal opinion.

Topic.Title: YHOO Bounce Report

Message.Msg: Really good

Message.Title: Yahoo Annual Report February 28th
Message.Msg: Anyone care to comment (pro or con) on the following which was taking from their most recent 10-K Under the Search Agreement, Microsoft generally guarantees Yahoo!’s revenue per search (“RPS Guarantee”) on Yahoo! Properties for 18 months after the transition of paid search services to Microsoft’s platform in a particular market. In the fourth quarter of 2011, Microsoft agreed to extend the RPS Guarantee in the U.S. and Canada through March 2013. The RPS Guarantee is calculated based on the difference in revenue per search between the pre-transition and post-transition periods and certain other factors. To date, there has been a gap in revenue per search between pre-transition and post-transition periods and Microsoft has been making payments under the RPS Guarantee to compensate for the difference. To the extent the RPS Guarantee payments we receive do not fully offset any shortfall relating to revenue per search in transitioned markets or the RPS Guarantee in transitioned markets expires before the gap in revenue per search is closed, our search revenue and profitability would decline. If the RPS Guarantee in the U.S. and Canada is not renewed prior to its expiration on March 31, 2013, we currently anticipate that our revenue, cash flows and income will be negatively impacted. Notwithstanding any RPS Guarantee payments that we may receive, our competitors may increase revenue, profitability, and market share at a higher rate than us.
